title: How to Make Apple Cider Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line your baking sheets with parchment paper.
steps.description: Use an non-rimmed baking sheet if you can; this will make removing the parchment paper and cookies easier later on.

steps.headline: Mix together the flour, baking soda, salt, ground pecans, and spices.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl, then add the baking soda, salt, and ground pecans. Next, add the ground cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg. Stir everything together until the pecans and spices are evenly distributed throughout the flour.

steps.headline: Cream together the sugar and butter in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Cut the butter into small cubes, and put it into a bowl. Add the sugar, than beat them together using a handheld better until they come together and turn light and fluffy. You can also use an electric mixer or food processor for this.

steps.headline: Add the egg into the butter mixture and beat again.
steps.description: Keep beating until the yolk breaks and gets mixed into the butter mixture. You don't want to see any streaks of egg yolk.

steps.headline: Add the flour mixture in two parts, beating well after each addition.
steps.description: Add half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture, and beat until it is evenly mixed in. Repeat with the remaining half of the flour.

steps.headline: Beat in the apples and apple cider using a low speed setting.
steps.description: You can peel the apples first, or leave them unpeeled for extra texture. Make sure that you grate them using a large grate; this will give you a chunkier texture. Use apples that are suitable for baking, such as Honeycrisp, Gala, Pink Lady, Macoun, Jonagold, or Cortland.

steps.headline: Drop the batter onto the prepared baking sheets using a tablespoon.
steps.description: You can also use something that is a similar size, such as a cookie scoop. Space the cookies 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) apart so that they can spread. Don't worry about flattening the cookies; they will flatten on their own as they bake.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Check the cookies at 20 minutes first, then decide whether you need to bake them longer. They are ready when they start turning golden around the edges.

steps.headline: Transfer the cookies to a wire cooling rack.
steps.description: If you are using an non-rimmed baking sheet, simply place the baking sheet on the same level as the cooling rack, then slide the parchment paper with the cookies off the baking sheet and onto the rack. If you used a rimmed baking sheet: carefully lift the parchment paper off of the baking sheet, and transfer it with the cookies onto a wire cooling rack.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool for a few minutes before serving them.
steps.description: They are perfect for fall, and make a great Thanksgiving treat! Store any leftover cookies in an airtight container, and eat them within 3 to 4 days..

steps.headline: Mix together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and spices.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl, then add the baking soda, baking powder, ground cinnamon, and ground allspice. Mix everything together until the spices are evenly distributed throughout the flour, then set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Cream together the butter, sugar, salt, and the powdered apple cider drink mix in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Cut the butter into cubes, and put it into separate mixing bowl. Add the sugar, salt, and powdered apple cider drink mix. Beat the ingredients together until everything is mixed in, and the butter turns light and fluffy. You can do this using an electric mixer or by hand. Make sure that you are using the regular kind of apple cider drink mix, and not the sugar-free kind). You will need to use all 10 7.4-ounce (21-gram) packets. Don't dissolve the apple cider powder first. Simply add it to the butter.

steps.headline: Add the eggs in one at a time, beating well after each one, then add the vanilla.
steps.description: Add your first egg into the butter mixture, then beat it in well. Add your next egg, and beat the butter mixture again. Finally, beat in the vanilla extract. Keep mixing until the texture and color are consistent, and there are not streaks or swirls of egg yolk or vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Add the flour mixture in two additions, beating well after each addition.
steps.description: Pour in half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture, then beat it in until it is completely mixed in. Repeat the with remaining flour mixture. If you need to, knead the dough by hand towards the end.

steps.headline: Cover the dough, then refrigerate it for 1 hour.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap so that the dough doesn't dry out, then place the bowl into fridge. Leave it there for 1 hour.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line your cookie sheets with parchment paper.
steps.description: If you can, try to use non-rimmed baking sheets. This will make removing the parchment paper a lot easier in the end.

steps.headline: Scoop out a tablespoon of the dough, and insert a caramel candy.
steps.description: Roll the dough into a ball first, then flatten it slightly with your palm. Unwrap a caramel candy, and press it into the dough. Wrap the dough back over the caramel, sealing it in like a present. Make sure that there are no gaps, or the caramel will leak out.

steps.headline: Continue making the cookies in a similar manner, then place them on the baking sheet, 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) apart.
steps.description: The cookies will spread out as they bake, so the extra space between will ensure that they don't fuse together.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 12 to 14 minutes.
steps.description: Check the cookies at 12 minutes; if they are not ready, bake them for another 1 to 2 minutes. They are ready when they are lightly browned around the edges.

steps.headline: Transfer the parchment paper, with the cookies on it, to a wire cooling rack.
steps.description: If you are using an non-rimmed baking sheet, hold it on the same level as the cooling rack, then slide the parchment paper off of the baking sheet and onto the rack. If you are using a rimmed baking sheet, carefully lift the parchment paper off the baking sheet, and place it on the rack.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool enough so that they are firm, then flip them over and let them finish cooling.
steps.description: Use a slight twisting motion to get them off of the parchment paper. If the cookies are stuck to the parchment paper, stick them in the freezer for a few minutes. They'll come right off!

steps.headline: Serve the cookies.
steps.description: They make a perfect treat for a cold, fall day or Thanksgiving. It might be a good idea to warm your guests ahead of time that they are filled with caramel, however! Store any leftovers in an airtight container, and consume within 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Mix together the  flour, baking soda, salt, and spices.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl, then add the baking soda, salt, ground cinnamon, ground ginger, and ground cloves. Stir everything together until the spices are mixed evenly throughout the flour, then set the bowl aside. Need something gluten-free? Use gluten-free flour instead!

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Cut the butter into cubes, then put it into a separate mixing bowl. Add the sugar, then beat the two together using an electric beat set to high speed. Keep beating the two together until the butter turns light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Add the egg, applesauce, apple cider, molasses, and vanilla.
steps.description: Beat the mixture again until the color and texture are even. Don't worry if the mixture looks curdled or lumpy.

steps.headline: Add the flour mixture in two additions, beating well after each one.
steps.description: Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture, and beat it until it is evenly combined. Add the rest of the flour mixture, and beat it in once more.

steps.headline: Cover the dough, then refrigerate it for 2 hours.
steps.description: Place a sheet of plastic wrap over the bowl; this will keep the dough from drying out. Next, place the bowl into the fridge, and leave it there for 2 hours.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line your baking sheets with parchment paper.
steps.description: You can use rimmed or non-rimmed baking sheets for this.

steps.headline: Roll the dough into tablespoon sized balls.
steps.description: If you'd like, you can scoop it out using a cookie scoop instead. Place the cookie balls onto a non-stick surface, such as a sheet of wax paper. You can also place them onto your prepared baking sheet instead.

steps.headline: Roll the balls in a bowl of sugar, then place them on the baking sheet, 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) apart.
steps.description: Fill a shallow bowl or dish with granulated sugar. Take one of the balls of dough, and roll it around in the sugar until it is evenly coated. Place it on the baking sheet, and repeat with the remaining balls of dough. The sugar will give the cookies a nice texture. Don't flatten the balls; they will flatten and spread on their own.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Check the cookies after 10 minutes first, then back them longer if needed. The cookies may have a cracked texture on top, and they will be soft and chewing inside.

steps.headline: Let the cookies cool.
steps.description: Allow the cookies to rest for a minutes on the baking sheet, then transfer them to a wire cooling rack to finish. Allow the cookies to cool for about 5 minutes first, then pull them off the baking sheet using a twisting motion, and transfer them to a wire cooling rack to finish cooling.

steps.headline: Serve the cookies.
steps.description: They make the perfect treat for a cold, fall day as well as Thanksgiving. If you have any left over, put them into an airtight container, and eat then within 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Finished.
Finished.
